qas.question: To what ancient philosopher did Darwin trace some of his evolutionary ideas?
Whose ideas were summarized by Aristotle in the work Darwin studied?
How did medieval scholars view the Genesis creation story?
What kind of births did the Christian Church fathers believe occurred in nature?

answers.text: monstrous births from union between species, and spontaneous generation of life.

context: In later editions of the book, Darwin traced evolutionary ideas as far back as <a0_0>Aristotle<a0_0/>; the text he cites is a summary by Aristotle of the ideas of the earlier <a1_0>Greek philosopher Empedocles<a1_0/>. Early Christian Church Fathers and Medieval European scholars interpreted the Genesis creation narrative <a2_0>allegorically<a2_0/> rather than as a literal historical account; organisms were described by their mythological and heraldic significance as well as by their physical form. Nature was widely believed to be unstable and capricious, with <a3_0>monstrous births from union between species, and spontaneous generation of life.
